trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create a new Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create a new Machine Learning experiment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Step 3 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Create a new training experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Step 3 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Create a new training experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough Step 3: Create a new Azure Machine Learning experiment
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough Step 3: Create a new Azure Machine Learning experiment

trans-unit.source: This is the third step of the walkthrough, [Develop a predictive analytics solution in Azure Machine Learning](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)
trans-unit.target: This is the third step of the walkthrough, [Develop a predictive analytics solution in Azure Machine Learning](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)

trans-unit.source: [Create a Machine Learning workspace](machine-learning-walkthrough-1-create-ml-workspace.md)
trans-unit.target: [Create a Machine Learning workspace](machine-learning-walkthrough-1-create-ml-workspace.md)

trans-unit.source: [Upload existing data](machine-learning-walkthrough-2-upload-data.md)
trans-unit.target: [Upload existing data](machine-learning-walkthrough-2-upload-data.md)

trans-unit.source: **Create a new experiment**
trans-unit.target: **Create a new experiment**

trans-unit.source: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)
trans-unit.target: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)

trans-unit.source: [Deploy the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-5-publish-web-service.md)
trans-unit.target: [Deploy the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-5-publish-web-service.md)

trans-unit.source: [Access the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-6-access-web-service.md)
trans-unit.target: [Access the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-6-access-web-service.md)

trans-unit.source: The next step in this walkthrough is to create a new experiment in Machine Learning Studio that uses the dataset we uploaded.
trans-unit.target: The next step in this walkthrough is to create a new experiment in Machine Learning Studio that uses the dataset we uploaded.

trans-unit.source: In Studio, click **+NEW** at the bottom of the window.
trans-unit.target: In Studio, click **+NEW** at the bottom of the window.

trans-unit.source: Select **EXPERIMENT**, and then select "Blank Experiment".
trans-unit.target: Select **EXPERIMENT**, and then select "Blank Experiment".

trans-unit.source: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful
trans-unit.target: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] It's a good practice to fill in **Summary** and **Description** for the experiment in the **Properties** pane.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] It's a good practice to fill in **Summary** and **Description** for the experiment in the **Properties** pane.

trans-unit.source: These properties give you the chance to document the experiment so that anyone who looks at it later will understand your goals and methodology.
trans-unit.target: These properties give you the chance to document the experiment so that anyone who looks at it later will understand your goals and methodology.

trans-unit.source: In the module palette to the left of the experiment canvas, expand **Saved Datasets**.
trans-unit.target: In the module palette to the left of the experiment canvas, expand **Saved Datasets**.

trans-unit.source: Find the dataset you created under **My Datasets** and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the dataset you created under **My Datasets** and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: You can also find the dataset by entering the name in the **Search** box above the palette.
trans-unit.target: You can also find the dataset by entering the name in the **Search** box above the palette.

trans-unit.source: Prepare the data You can view the first 100 rows of the data and some statistical information for the whole dataset by clicking the output port of the dataset (the small circle at the bottom) and selecting **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: Prepare the data You can view the first 100 rows of the data and some statistical information for the whole dataset by clicking the output port of the dataset (the small circle at the bottom) and selecting **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: Because the data file didn't come with column headings, Studio has provided generic headings (Col1, Col2, *etc.*).
trans-unit.target: Because the data file didn't come with column headings, Studio has provided generic headings (Col1, Col2, *etc.*).

trans-unit.source: Good headings aren't essential to creating a model, but they will make it easier to work with the data in the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Good headings aren't essential to creating a model, but they will make it easier to work with the data in the experiment.

trans-unit.source: Also, when we eventually publish this model in a web service, the headings will help identify the columns to the user of the service.
trans-unit.target: Also, when we eventually publish this model in a web service, the headings will help identify the columns to the user of the service.

trans-unit.source: We can add column headings using the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module.
trans-unit.target: We can add column headings using the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module.

trans-unit.source: You use the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module to change metadata associated with a dataset.
trans-unit.target: You use the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module to change metadata associated with a dataset.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it can provide more friendly names for column headings.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it can provide more friendly names for column headings.

trans-unit.source: To use [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor], you first specify which columns to modify (in this case, all of them), then you specify the action to be performed on those columns (in this case, changing column headings).
trans-unit.target: To use [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor], you first specify which columns to modify (in this case, all of them), then you specify the action to be performed on those columns (in this case, changing column headings).

trans-unit.source: In the module palette, type "metadata" in the **Search** box.
trans-unit.target: In the module palette, type "metadata" in the **Search** box.

trans-unit.source: You'll see [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] appear in the module list.
trans-unit.target: You'll see [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] appear in the module list.

trans-unit.source: Click and drag the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module onto the canvas and drop it below the dataset we added earlier.
trans-unit.target: Click and drag the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module onto the canvas and drop it below the dataset we added earlier.

trans-unit.source: Connect the dataset to the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor]: click the output port of the dataset (the small circle at the bottom of the dataset), drag to the input port of [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] (the small circle at the top of the module), then release the mouse button.
trans-unit.target: Connect the dataset to the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor]: click the output port of the dataset (the small circle at the bottom of the dataset), drag to the input port of [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] (the small circle at the top of the module), then release the mouse button.

trans-unit.source: The dataset and module will remain connected even if you move either around on the canvas.
trans-unit.target: The dataset and module will remain connected even if you move either around on the canvas.

trans-unit.source: The experiment should now look something like this:
trans-unit.target: The experiment should now look something like this:

trans-unit.source: ![Adding Metadata Editor][2]
trans-unit.target: ![Adding Metadata Editor][2]

trans-unit.source: The red exclamation mark indicates that we haven't set the properties for this module yet.
trans-unit.target: The red exclamation mark indicates that we haven't set the properties for this module yet.

trans-unit.source: We'll do that next.
trans-unit.target: We'll do that next.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] You can add a comment to a module by double-clicking the module and entering text.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] You can add a comment to a module by double-clicking the module and entering text.

trans-unit.source: This can help you see at a glance what the module is doing in your experiment.
trans-unit.target: This can help you see at a glance what the module is doing in your experiment.

trans-unit.source: In this case, double-click the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module and type the comment "Add column headings".
trans-unit.target: In this case, double-click the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module and type the comment "Add column headings".

trans-unit.source: Click anywhere else on the canvas to close the text box.
trans-unit.target: Click anywhere else on the canvas to close the text box.

trans-unit.source: Click the down-arrow on the module to display the comment.
trans-unit.target: Click the down-arrow on the module to display the comment.

trans-unit.source: Select [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor], then in the **Properties** pane to the right of the canvas, click **Launch column selector**.
trans-unit.target: Select [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor], then in the **Properties** pane to the right of the canvas, click **Launch column selector**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Select columns** dialog, set the **Begin With** field to "All columns".
trans-unit.target: In the **Select columns** dialog, set the **Begin With** field to "All columns".

trans-unit.source: The row beneath **Begin With** allows you to include or exclude specific columns for [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] to modify.
trans-unit.target: The row beneath **Begin With** allows you to include or exclude specific columns for [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] to modify.

trans-unit.source: Since we want to modify *all* columns, delete this row by clicking the minus sign ("-") to the right of the row.
trans-unit.target: Since we want to modify *all* columns, delete this row by clicking the minus sign ("-") to the right of the row.

trans-unit.source: The dialog should look like this: ![Column Selector with all columns selected][4]
trans-unit.target: The dialog should look like this: ![Column Selector with all columns selected][4]

trans-unit.source: Click the **OK** checkmark.
trans-unit.target: Click the **OK** checkmark.

trans-unit.source: Back in the **Properties** pane, look for the **New column names** parameter.
trans-unit.target: Back in the **Properties** pane, look for the **New column names** parameter.

trans-unit.source: In this field, enter a list of names for the 21 columns in the dataset, separated by commas and in column order.
trans-unit.target: In this field, enter a list of names for the 21 columns in the dataset, separated by commas and in column order.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain the columns names from the dataset documentation on the UCI website, or for convenience you can copy and paste the following list:
trans-unit.target: You can obtain the columns names from the dataset documentation on the UCI website, or for convenience you can copy and paste the following list:

trans-unit.source: The Properties pane will look like this:
trans-unit.target: The Properties pane will look like this:

trans-unit.source: ![Properties for Metadata Editor][1]
trans-unit.target: ![Properties for Metadata Editor][1]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] If you want to verify the column headings, run the experiment (click **RUN** below the experiment canvas).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] If you want to verify the column headings, run the experiment (click **RUN** below the experiment canvas).

trans-unit.source: When it finishes running (a green checkmark will appear on [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor]), click the output port of the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module, and select **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: When it finishes running (a green checkmark will appear on [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor]), click the output port of the [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module, and select **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: You can view the output of any module in the same way to view the progress of the data through the experiment.
trans-unit.target: You can view the output of any module in the same way to view the progress of the data through the experiment.

trans-unit.source: Create training and test datasets
trans-unit.target: Create training and test datasets

trans-unit.source: The next step of the experiment is to generate separate datasets that we'll use for both training and testing our model.
trans-unit.target: The next step of the experiment is to generate separate datasets that we'll use for both training and testing our model.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we use the [Split Data][split] module.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we use the [Split Data][split] module.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Split Data][split] module, drag it onto the canvas, and connect it to the last [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Split Data][split] module, drag it onto the canvas, and connect it to the last [Metadata Editor][metadata-editor] module.

trans-unit.source: By default, the split ratio is 0.5 and the **Randomized split** parameter is set.
trans-unit.target: By default, the split ratio is 0.5 and the **Randomized split** parameter is set.

trans-unit.source: This means that a random half of the data will be output through one port of the [Split Data][split] module, and half through the other.
trans-unit.target: This means that a random half of the data will be output through one port of the [Split Data][split] module, and half through the other.

trans-unit.source: You can adjust these, as well as the **Random seed** parameter, to change the split between training and testing data.
trans-unit.target: You can adjust these, as well as the **Random seed** parameter, to change the split between training and testing data.

trans-unit.source: For this example we'll leave them as-is.
trans-unit.target: For this example we'll leave them as-is.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] The property **Fraction of rows in the first output dataset** determines how much of the data is output through the left output port.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] The property **Fraction of rows in the first output dataset** determines how much of the data is output through the left output port.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you set the ratio to 0.7, then 70% of the data is output through the left port and 30% through the right port.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you set the ratio to 0.7, then 70% of the data is output through the left port and 30% through the right port.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the [Split Data][split] module and enter the comment, "Training/testing data split 50%".
trans-unit.target: Double-click the [Split Data][split] module and enter the comment, "Training/testing data split 50%".

trans-unit.source: We can use the outputs of the [Split Data][split] module however we like, but let's choose to use the left output as training data and the right output as testing data.
trans-unit.target: We can use the outputs of the [Split Data][split] module however we like, but let's choose to use the left output as training data and the right output as testing data.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned on the UCI website, the cost of misclassifying a high credit risk as low is 5 times larger than the cost of misclassifying a low credit risk as high.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned on the UCI website, the cost of misclassifying a high credit risk as low is 5 times larger than the cost of misclassifying a low credit risk as high.

trans-unit.source: To account for this, we'll generate a new dataset that reflects this cost function.
trans-unit.target: To account for this, we'll generate a new dataset that reflects this cost function.

trans-unit.source: In the new dataset, each high risk example is replicated 5 times, while each low risk example is not replicated.
trans-unit.target: In the new dataset, each high risk example is replicated 5 times, while each low risk example is not replicated.

trans-unit.source: We can do this replication using R code:
trans-unit.target: We can do this replication using R code:

trans-unit.source: Find and drag the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module onto the experiment canvas and connect the left output port of the [Split Data][split] module to the first input port ("Dataset1") of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Find and drag the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module onto the experiment canvas and connect the left output port of the [Split Data][split] module to the first input port ("Dataset1") of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module and enter the comment, "Set cost adjustment".
trans-unit.target: Double-click the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module and enter the comment, "Set cost adjustment".

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** pane, delete the default text in the **R Script** parameter and enter this script:
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** pane, delete the default text in the **R Script** parameter and enter this script:

trans-unit.source: We need to do this same replication operation for each output of the [Split Data][split] module so that the training and testing data have the same cost adjustment.
trans-unit.target: We need to do this same replication operation for each output of the [Split Data][split] module so that the training and testing data have the same cost adjustment.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module and select **Copy**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module and select **Copy**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the experiment canvas and select **Paste**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the experiment canvas and select **Paste**.

trans-unit.source: Connect the first input port of this [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module to the right output port of the [Split Data][split] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the first input port of this [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module to the right output port of the [Split Data][split] module.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] The copy of the Execute R Script module contains the same script as the original module.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] The copy of the Execute R Script module contains the same script as the original module.

trans-unit.source: When you copy and paste a module on the canvas, the copy retains all the properties of the original.
trans-unit.target: When you copy and paste a module on the canvas, the copy retains all the properties of the original.

trans-unit.source: Our experiment now looks something like this:
trans-unit.target: Our experiment now looks something like this:

trans-unit.source: ![Adding Split module and R scripts][3]
trans-unit.target: ![Adding Split module and R scripts][3]

trans-unit.source: For more information on using R scripts in your experiments, see [Extend your experiment with R](machine-learning-extend-your-experiment-with-r.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on using R scripts in your experiments, see [Extend your experiment with R](machine-learning-extend-your-experiment-with-r.md).

trans-unit.source: **Next: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)**
trans-unit.target: **Next: [Train and evaluate the models](machine-learning-walkthrough-4-train-and-evaluate-models.md)**

trans-unit.target: [execute-r-script]: https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5/ [metadata-editor]: https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66/ [split]: https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/70530644-c97a-4ab6-85f7-88bf30a8be5f/
